If I could change one historical event, I would choose to prevent the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914. This event led to the outbreak of World War I, which caused immense human suffering, destruction, and reshaped the global political landscape. By preventing this event, I believe I could have prevented the war and its aftermath, including the Russian Revolution, the rise of fascist and nationalist movements, and the Holocaust.

I would change the outcome of the Battle of Little Bighorn in 1876. The defeat of the 7th Cavalry Regiment led by Lt. Col. George Custer at the hands of the Lakota, Cheyenne, and Arapaho warriors was a significant turning point in the history of the American West. By changing the outcome of this battle, I believe I could have prevented the forced relocation of Native American tribes, the loss of their land and culture, and the ongoing systemic oppression they face today.

I would alter the course of the American Civil War by preventing the Emancipation Proclamation from being issued in 1863. The Emancipation Proclamation, while a significant step towards the abolition of slavery, did not actually free any slaves. By preventing its issuance, I believe I could have prevented the further suffering and exploitation of enslaved people, and potentially led to a more peaceful and less divisive resolution to the conflict.

I would undo the Treaty of Versailles, which ended World War I in 1919. The harsh terms of the treaty, including the War Guilt Clause and the reparations imposed on Germany, contributed to the rise of fascist and nationalist movements in Europe, including Nazi Germany, and ultimately led to the outbreak of World War II. By preventing the Treaty of Versailles, I believe I could have prevented the devastation and loss of life that occurred in the second world war.
